Title: Floating Housing Related Support for Young People Aged 16 – 25 Years Old (North and South) and Generic Floating Housing Related Support (North and South)
Description:
The aim of the Service is to provide short term, intensive, floating Housing Related Support for young people and young parents aged 16 to 25 years old living in the community with various types of properties regardless of the tenure.  The floating support should not last more than two years.  Housing Related Support will enable Customers to gain the skills, knowledge and experience to secure and/or maintain their own accommodation and live independently, thus preventing, reducing and/or delaying their need for care and support through homelessness.

The aim of the Service is to provide short term, intensive, Housing Related Support lasting not more than one year for Customers aged 25 years and above. Description:
Warwickshire County Council wish to commission a single provider to deliver a Local Healthwatch Service within Warwickshire.
      
      The local Healthwatch Service within Warwickshire will be the independent consumer champion for the public to promote better outcomes in health and in social care - locally via Local Healthwatch organisations and nationally via Healthwatch England. 
      
      The local Healthwatch service in Warwickshire will be representative of the diverse communities it serves. It will provide intelligence - including evidence from people's views and experiences - to influence the policy, planning, commissioning and delivery of publicly-funded health and social care services. It will also provide information to help people access and make choices about services as well as provide signposting to those who wish to make a complaint about NHS services.
      
      The local Healthwatch service in Warwickshire will be a robust and credible player in the local health and social care economy by demonstrating that it has the appropriate level of skills and competencies required to deliver its statutory functions. It will gain the trust of the general public as well as other health and social care stakeholder groups and organisations by being responsive, acting on concerns when things go wrong and being able to constructively challenge health and social care commissioners and providers.
      
      The seven key functions of the local Healthwatch Service are:
      
      1. Gather views and experiences of patients and the public
      2. Make these views known, both locally and nationally as appropriate
      3. Promote and support involvement in commissioning of health services and provision of care services
      4. Recommend investigation or special review of services via Healthwatch England or directly to the Care Quality Commission (CQC)
      5. Provide advice and information about access to services and support for making informed choices
      6. Make known the views and experiences of people to other local Healthwatch organisations and Healthwatch England and provide a steer to help it carry out its role as a national champion
      7. Access and refer customers to NHS Complaints Advocacy Services

      Housing Related Support 4 key principles:
      
      1.  A service must aim to prevent and/or reduce the escalation of the client's 
           needs and act to protect and enhance their opportunity of wellbeing.
      
      2.  A service must support those who are in need and eligible as determined by
           a Care Act 2014  assessment to maximize their independence and to reduce
           their risk of needing long term and/or acute care.
      
      3.  A service must be targeted on people who are assessed as vulnerable to not
           being able to sustain their independence or gain their independence. 
           Vulnerability is likely to be identified through multiple needs (for example 
           homelessness and mental health issues or offending behaviour) with one 
           main need being complicated by others or a combination of lower level 
           issues that together give cause for concerns in terms of ability to maintain 
           independence ('edge of care').
      
      4.  A Housing Related Support service should complement other services 
           provided and should represent an effective use of resources based on need.  
      
      Customers - Adults with disabilities who are residing in Warwickshire aged 16 years and over who would benefit from short term Housing Related floating Support
